meta: Abusing cURL and Bash for Mischief
description: Troll mode was initially intended - and written - to be a command line utility for bash. Three days into the project I learned more about the language and environment, realized this made no sense, and deleted the vast majority of code Iâ€™d written. The final version was refactored down to a single 23 line file. Since this project is essentially malware (of the harmless prank variety), I learned a lot about linux security.

meta: A crowd-sourced nest finder for Pokemon GO
description: I made it into the Pokemon Go beta and so had a few weeks to play the game before anyone else. I figured something folks would want when it came out would be a way to track where they caught certain Pokemon and share that information with their friends. I built the app with a Django backend and used the Google Maps API.

meta: Guideline for writing good user models
description: I wrote an article to teach Django beginners how to start a project with good user models that don't turn into a hassle down the line. It's a simplified starter that can work for hackathons and whatnot.

header: How Are You Gonna Pay For It?
meta: A visualization for federal budget items
description: Something I built to make conversations around taxes and government spending less boring. The data is pulled from the 2018 federal budget provided by api.usaspending.gov. I built this in a week during which I also wrote React for the first time.

Making HowAreYouGonnaPayForIt got me really excited about React. This was my second project using the library and I built it over the course of a boring 2.5 hour lecture. It's a tool to quickly estimate conversions between hourly, monthly, and yearly pay.
This website is a static single-page app hosted on Github pages. I've been working on it for a while and am happy to have finally finished it.

meta: The coolest take-home interview I've ever done
description: I got permission to publicly post my solution to this interview problem. The company gave me a target and asked me to write a script that would exploit a SQL injection vulnerability.
A Capture the Flag competition that involved topics from Linux Exploitation to Reverse Engineering. I came in ~30th place out of ~1000.

I got a big group of people who knew nothing/very little about hacking (there was no limit to group size) to see if we could get any flags if we learned how to do this stuff on the fly. We did end up getting a couple of flags but obviously came nowhere close to winning.

meta: Experimenting with different distros for fun
description: My personal computer is usually running some version of Linux. I've tried several Debian-derived distros and am currently trying Arch. My next experiment is either going to be regular Debian or Manjaro.

meta: Research on Cross Site Scripting in React
description: I wrote an article and built some example apps demonstrating common ways XSS vulnerabilities make it into React applications.

meta: How to deploy Flask to Heroku
description: An easy and detailed tutorial for deploying Flask to Heroku. Especially targeted to folks who are just learning how to code and are maybe deploying their first ever project.

Typo generator uses a markov chain written in python to produce funny and weird typos - much like a drunk human would make. There's also a My Immortal tweet generator on the same heroku deployment but just ignore that.
live_link_text: Heroku deployment (give it a few seconds to boot up)

meta: An Article about Logarithmic Time Complexity
description: My most read article is about time complexity. Google uses the diagrams I created for it sometimes to illustrate searches related to logarithms.
